This Monday I read a report in the newspaper Marca that I found quite interesting. Under the title The most expensive football in Europe, the journalists in charge of the study compare the average ticket prices of the four major European leagues. Result: the average cost of a ticket in Spain is 53 euros, in Italy’s Serie A 48, in the Premier League 44 and in the Bundesliga 30. With the minimum wages -and not so minimum wages- that we have in Spain, the current unemployment situation, and the difference in purchasing power with other European countries calls attention to this inequality. I found it curious, to say the least, to see how a ticket for a 2ªB Oviedo-La Roda match costs 25 euros, while the Champions League Leverkusen-Barça match could be seen from 15 euros.

Different prices depending on the rival

The reporters wonder why this price madness in Spain, and conclude:

  • The schedules are not conducive to going to the stadiums. A Monday at 9:00 p.m. or a Sunday at 9:30 p.m. is not the best time to go to the field. People don’t go and prices remain high.
  • The stadiums are not more comfortable than in the rest of Europe, on the contrary, there are problems with parking, access, temperature, etc. So the price is high not precisely for the comfort of the viewer.
  • Pay television suitable for all pockets – Gol TV for example – distances the public from the stadiums. In addition, open matches are added to it.
  • Match schedules are unknown well in advance to encourage team travel. To this is added that many times higher prices are charged to fans of the visiting team.

Of course, there are differences between the Spanish clubs, but we’ll talk about that another day if you want.
